Project Description  The  Lanzhou–Chongqing  Railway  (LCR)  Development  Project  is  in 
Chongqing  municipality  and  the  northwestern  part  of  Sichuan  and 
Gansu  provinces—a  relatively  poor  area.  It  is  designed  to  promote 
sustainable economic growth by building 820 kilometers (km) of railway 
line from Lanzhou, the capital city of Gansu province, to Chongqing. The 
Project will (i) develop an efficient, safe, affordable, and environmentally 
sustainable  railway  transport  system  in  the  region;  and  (ii)  help  create 
more employment and income-generating opportunities, thus benefiting 
poor residents.  
 
The  Project  reflects  ADB’s  operational  strategy  for  the  PRC  railway 
sector,  which 
includes  reducing  railway  network  constraints  and 
promoting  sustainable  economic  growth  in  poor  areas  not  served  by 
railways.  The  Project  is  also  in  line  with  the  Government’s  western 
development  strategy  of  providing  less-developed  regions  with  better 
infrastructure  to  facilitate  economic  growth,  thereby  giving  people  a 
better opportunity to improve their living standards.  

 
Rationale 

The  interior  regions  of  the  PRC  have  not  benefited  as  much  from 
economic  growth  and  reforms  as  the  east  coast;  in  fact,  the  gap 
between  economic  and  social  development  in  those  regions  has 
increased.  Transport  constraints  and  high  logistics  costs  contribute  to 
the  economic  disparities  between  the  regions  and  prevent  the  western 
region from capitalizing on its comparative advantages. 

The Project will be (i) the first north–south railway line linking Chongqing 
municipality  and  Gansu,  Shaanxi,  and  Sichuan  provinces;  and  (ii)  the 
shortest  north–south  corridor  linking  Lanzhou,  Baoji,  Yinchuan,  Xining, 
Xinjiang,  and  other  major  cities  in  the  north  to  Chongqing,  Chengdu, 
Guiyang,  Kunming,  and  other  ports  and  cities  in  the  south.  The 
proposed alignment for the LCR is shorter by 295 km and 600 km than 
the  two  existing  routes  between  Lanzhou  and  Chongqing.  Traversing 
Gansu,  Shaanxi,  and  Sichuan  provinces  and  Chongqing  municipality, 
the  proposed  railway  line  will  connect  with  the  Baotou–Yinchuan–
Lanzhou in the northeast; Urumqi–Lanzhou in the northwest on its way 
to  Kazakhstan  and  Europe;  Shanghai–Wuhan–Ankang  in  the  east,  at

The project company, a joint venture of the Ministry of Railways (MOR) 
and the Chongqing municipal, Gansu provincial, and Sichuan provincial 
governments, will have substantial managerial and financial autonomy. It 
will  help  change  railway  enterprises  from  cost  centers  in  a  planned 
economy  to  profit  centers  in  an  increasingly  competitive  transport 
market.  The  components  have  been  formulated  in  line  with  MOR’s 
railway development plan for 2004. 
 
The  impact  of  the  Project  will  be  an  improved  transport  system  in  the 
region  that  supports  socioeconomic  development  and  the  western 
development  strategy.  Providing  economic  railway  transportation  in 
unserved, less-developed, and poor areas will help create the conditions 
for local resource development, more jobs, and higher incomes and thus 
raise living standards in the project area.  
 
Project  preparation  was  participatory.  All  the  main  stakeholders—
various affected people, potential beneficiaries, village leaders, women’s 
groups,  local  ethnic  bureaus,  and  local  governments  in  the  project 
area—were extensively consulted. Household surveys and participatory 
workshops  in  the  project  area  elicited  public  opinion  about  the  Project 
and useful information for the social and environmental assessments. 
 
The Project has the following components: (i) the construction of 820 km 
of  double-track  electrified  standard-gauge  class  I  railway  from  Lanzhou 
to  Chongqing;  (ii)  the  construction  of  31  new  railway  stations  complete 
with  facilities;  (iii)  the  provision  of  modern  technology  and  equipment, 
among  other  initiatives,  to  improve  safety;  (iv)  the  introduction  of  a 
signaling, communication, and management information system; (v) the 
provision  of  training  in  the  use  and  maintenance  of  the  modern 
equipment;  (vi)  land  acquisition  and  resettlement;  (vii)  environmental 
protection  and  mitigation  of  adverse  environmental  effects; 
(viii) consulting  services  for  construction  supervision,  monitoring  and 
evaluation,  and  marketing  and  business  development;  and  (ix)  the 
strengthening  of  institutional  capabilities.  Project  implementation  will 
require these key inputs: civil works, equipment, consultants, and MOR 
and project company staff.  
 
The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $8,608.9 million.

The major project beneficiaries will be (i) the Government, which stands 
to  gain  from  improved  safety  and  a  lower  energy  bill;  (ii)  passengers, 
including  tourists,  for  whom  travel  will  be  affordable,  faster,  and  safer; 
(iii) freight  users,  who  switch  from  the  existing  road  and  benefit  from 
more affordable, faster, and safer trips; (iv) local residents, who will pay 
less for goods and services transported by the project railway; (v) local 
labor hired to build the railway, supply materials during construction, and 
load and unload goods during operation; (vi) local farmers, who can sell 
their products at market prices without having to pay a high margin to a 
transport  intermediary;  (vii) manufacturers  and  traders,  who  can  set  up 
businesses,  produce  more,  and  transport  their  goods  and  services  by 
the  railway;  and  (viii) local  governments,  which  will  have  greater 
opportunity for local area development and higher tax revenues. 
 
The  Project  will  benefit  about  16.8  million  people  living  in  the  project 
area. The poverty and social assessment looked at the 28 counties and 
districts  in  the  area,  including  15  designated  national  poverty  counties 
and  2,897  designated  poverty  villages.  About  72%  of  the  beneficiaries 
are  rural,  and  17%  are  poor,  with  an  annual  net  income  per  capita  of 
less  than  CNY1,000.  The  links  between  poverty,  difficult  topography, 
and poor transport systems are apparent in the project area. Poverty is 
often caused by geographic remoteness and isolation, limited transport 
access, high transport costs, and poor access to market information, as 
well as limited access to health, education, and other social services. 
 
The  Project  will  give  rise  to  more  jobs  and  income  opportunities.  The 
468,000  or  so  person-years  of  work  during  construction  will  provide 
direct  employment  for  over  234,000  poor  people,  including women  and 
ethnic  minorities.  Railway  station  area  development  will  boost  the 
incomes of communities and produce tax revenues. The development of 
small  businesses,  local  industry,  and  tourism  through  the  Project  will 
increase  opportunities  in  the  future  for  local  people.  Consultations  with 
local people in the project area indicated strong support for the Project. 
 
The  Project  is  financially  and  economically  sustainable.  The  6.98% 
financial  internal  rate  of  return  exceeds  the  2.74%  weighted  average 
cost of capital. The economic internal rate of return is 17.09%.  
 
The increased tax revenues from the economic development induced by 
the Project will help finance improvements in social service facilities and 
basic infrastructure. 
 
The  construction  of  the  railway,  in  mountainous  areas,  presents  a 
significant  technical  challenge.  Construction  could  be  delayed,  cost 
more than expected, compromise the health and safety of workers, and 
adversely  affect  the  environment.  These  potential  risks  have  been 
assessed and mitigating measures based on lessons learned from other 
railway projects in the PRC have been provided.

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Lanzhou–Chongqing  Railway  (LCR) 
Development Project. The report also describes proposed administration of technical assistance

From  1978,  when  market-oriented  economic  reforms  were  introduced  in  the  PRC,  to 
2007, the country went through sustained rapid economic growth, and a resulting rapid increase 
in  demand  for  transportation.  Passenger  transport  grew  by  9%  yearly  and  freight  transport  by 
7.6%. Railways are the principal mode of freight transport in the PRC, with 47.5% of total freight 
ton-kilometers  (ton-km)  in  2006,  followed  by  27.9%  for  inland  waterways  and  sea-to-shore 
shipping,  21.1%  for  roads,  3.3%  for  pipelines,  and  0.2%  for  civil  aviation.  In  2006,  road  traffic 
accounted for 52.8% of total passenger-kilometers (pass-km), followed by railways with 34.5%, 
civil aviation with 12.3%, and coastal and inland waterways with 0.4%. 
 
3. 
The railway is the primary mode of long-distance and bulk transport. At the end of 2007, 
the  PRC’s  78,000  route-kilometers  (route-km)  of  railways  comprised  63,600  km  of  national 
railways and 14,400 km of joint-venture and local railways. The Ministry of Railways (MOR) runs 
the state-owned national railway as an integrated system. The joint-venture and local railways, 
regional  lines  within  provincial  boundaries,  are  built  under  provincial  government  or  MOR 
sponsorship to serve local needs and interconnect with the national railway network. Despite its 
large size, however, the railway network does not provide adequate coverage for the country’s 
population and land area.1  
 
4. 
PRC railways have the highest freight transport density in the world and second-highest 
passenger transport density after Japan. Locomotive turnover is the highest in the world. From 
1978  to  2007,  railway  freight  increased  from  535  billion  ton-km  to  2,380  billion  ton-km,  or  by 
5.28%  yearly,  and  passenger  traffic  grew  by  6.74%  yearly,  from  109 billion  pass-km  to 
722 billion pass-km. For passenger trips, the average railway journey increased from 134 km in 
1978 to 532 km in 2007, compared with road travel, which grew from 35 km to 55 km over the 
same  period.  For  freight,  the  average  railway  journey  in  2007  was  757  km,  compared  with 
65 km  for  road  transport.  Yet,  despite  such  growth  rates,  railway  capacity  has  lagged  behind 
demand  because  of  system  constraints.  Given  the  railways’  important  role  in  economic 
transportation,  these  constraints,  if  not  removed,  will  continue  to  hamper  efficient  economic 
growth. The Government’s aggressive plan to improve railways includes network expansion and 
construction in underserved areas.

6. 
In  2004,  the  State  Council  approved  a  railway  development  plan  for  the  period  up  to 
2020.  The  plan  seeks  to  expand  the  railway  network  to  100,000  km  by  2020.  Increasing  train 
speed  is  a major  goal. Priority  will be  given  to the  development  of  railways  in  unserved  areas 
and regions that lack transport and have remained less developed. Route network length in the 
western  region  of  the  PRC  will  increase  by  16,000  km,  to  40,000  km,  by  2020.  To  improve 
operating  efficiency,  MOR  has  begun  to  separate  passenger  and  freight  trains  on  key  rail

7. 
The  11th  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010)  highlights  railway  development  and  accelerated 
railway  construction.  It  foresees  (i)  the  construction  of  17,000  km  of  new  lines,  for  a  total 
network  length  of  92,000  route-km;  and  (ii) the  conversion  of  45%  of  the  network  length  into 
double-track  electrified  railway.  The  plan  seeks  to  (i)  build  a  dedicated  passenger  railway 
network through the construction of 7,000 km of passenger-dedicated lines by 2010; (ii) develop 
coal transport corridors by increasing the capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand the railway 
network  in  the  poor  western  region  (to  34,000  km);  (iv)  build  international  corridors  at  the 
southwest and northwest borders; and (v) develop a nationwide intermodal container network. A 
total  investment  of  CNY1.5  trillion  (about  $200 billion)—CNY1.25  trillion  for  construction  and 
CNY250 billion for rolling stock—is planned in the 11th Five-Year Plan, of which a total of CNY 
465.2 billion has been spent in 2006 and 2007 (Appendix 3).

4. 

Lessons  

 
The  report  on  the  evaluation  of  ADB  assistance  to  the  transport  sector  in  the  PRC17 
20. 
pronounced  ADB’s  program  for  railways  a  success.  The  report  noted  that  ADB’s  strategic 
priorities in the railway subsector were well aligned with the country’s needs. Its overall focus on 
building  railways  with  modern  technologies  met  the  need  to  increase  railway  capacity  and 
reduce  the  persistent  gap  between  supply  and  demand  as  quickly  and  efficiently  as  possible. 
The priority given by ADB to improving efficiency and commercial orientation and its emphasis 
on policy restructuring and reform matched the evolving institutional reforms in railways. 
 
Completed  and ongoing ADB-financed railway projects in the PRC show the executing 
21. 
agencies’  strong  commitment  and  generally  satisfactory  capabilities  for project  implementation 
(Appendix 7). The speed of implementation has generally exceeded expectations at appraisal, 
and  agencies  have  generally  complied  with  loan  covenants.  Resettlement  and  environmental 
management  have  been  satisfactory.  Audit  covenants  have  been  complied  with  in  a  timely 
manner,  and  the  audited  financial  statements  have  been  generally  acceptable.  Of  the  15 
ADB-supported railway projects, 10 have been completed, and 5 are being implemented. 
 
The completed railway projects highlight the need to (i) ensure that the executing agency 
22. 
established  for  project  processing,  implementation,  and  operation  has  adequate  capacity; 
(ii) prepare  realistic  traffic  forecasts;  (iii)  review  network-wide  constraints  on  traffic  and  the 
impact on project viability of existing and planned railway lines and other transportation modes 
that may compete with project facilities; (iv) make realistic resettlement projections at appraisal; 
and (v) finance railway projects with appropriately determined debt–equity ratios.

The  Project  will  (i)  enhance  capacity  and  reduce  the  bottlenecks  through  network 
development;  (ii)  improve  energy  efficiency  and  environmental  sustainability  by  providing  a 
more efficient and environment-friendly mode of transport in the corridor; (iii)  improve safety by

economic growth needed to reduce rural poverty has not materialized. Local governments and 
people living in the project area see the railway as a key investment for addressing this problem.

57. 
The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated through a comparison of the 
with- and without-Project situations. The Project will reduce the cost of transport to and from the 
poor central and northwestern part of Gansu, Shaanxi, and Sichuan provinces and Chongqing 
municipality,  and  will  provide  economic  opportunities  in  the  unserved  areas  of  Gansu  and 
Sichuan  provinces  (Supplementary  Appendix  D).  Economic  costs  include  construction, 
operation,  and  maintenance  costs,  and  the  value  of  agricultural  production  from  land  lost 
permanently.  Economic  benefits  include  (i) operating  cost  savings  for  freight  and  passenger 
traffic,  (ii)  time  savings  in  diverted  passenger  traffic  from  buses,  (iii)  transport  benefits 
generated, (iv) tourism benefits, (v) shipper savings because of increased railway competition, 
(vi)  road  accidents  avoided,  (vii)  pollution  reduction  benefits,  (viii)  energy  savings,  and 
(ix) national  productivity  benefits.  The  project  EIRR  is  17.09%,  indicating  that  the  Project  is 
economically viable (Appendix 15). Sensitivity analysis confirms the robustness of the Project’s 
economic  viability.  Changes  in  the  key  variables,  such  as  a  20%  reduction  in  benefits,  do  not 
significantly affect economic viability. The total cost would have to increase by 23% over those 
estimated for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. Freight benefits would have to fall by 
25%  and  passenger  benefits  by  175%.  Given  ADB’s  experience  in  the  PRC  railway  sector, 
variations  of  such  magnitude  are  unlikely.  Project  risks  were  quantified  through  the  statistical 
method,  i.e.,  considering  the  possible  value  for  key  variables  and  the  probability  of  their 
occurrence. The result shows that the EIRR will exceed 12%, with 100% probability. Distribution 
analysis, undertaken by determining the project effects for various beneficiaries, indicates that a 
large portion of net benefits will accrue to project users and the economy.

per million ton-km. This value was included in the benefit stream (CNY54.62 million in 2015). In 
addition, the saving in reduced total fuel consumption (CNY616.01 million in 2015) as a result of 
diverting traffic from both road and rail to LCR was computed and included in the benefit stream. 
Unit operating costs for both road and rail transport were adjusted to exclude fuel costs in order 
to eliminate double counting of this benefit.  
 
9.

absence  of  LCR.  The  economic  analysis  estimated  four  such  cases  of  cost  avoidance; 
(i) highway  investment  costs  avoided;  (ii)  highway  routine  and  periodic  maintenance  costs 
avoided;  (iii)  truck  shipping  charges  to  freight  shippers  avoided  through  increased  competition 
brought about by LCR; and (iv) road accident costs avoided.  
 
10. 
Conclusion.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  for  the  Project  is  17.09% 
(Table A15.3). Benefits from freight traffic, including generated benefits, are the major economic 
benefit (about 63.8% for freight shippers in Table A15.2), with passenger benefits contributing 
about 4.9% and other benefits making up the balance. Sensitivity analysis tested 10 scenarios 
to assess the robustness of the results of the economic analysis (Table A15.4). The total cost 
would have to be more than 23% higher than estimated for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate 
of  12%.  Considering  the  experience  of  ADB-financed  projects  in  the  railway  sector,  this 
switching value is unlikely to occur. The freight benefits would have to decrease by about 25% 
to  make  the  Project  economically  nonviable.  A  1-year  delay  in  completion  would  not  affect 
economic  viability  but,  again,  this  is  unlikely,  as  MOR  has  demonstrated  the  capacity  to 
implement and complete projects on schedule. Combinations of adverse effects of benefits and 
costs were also tested. The results showed that the Project would maintain its economic viability 
under plausible scenarios of variability.

show  that  the  EIRR  would  exceed  12%  with  100%  probability.  Distribution  analysis  examined

beneficiaries,  such  as  passengers,  freight  shippers,  labor,  government,  and  the  economy

2. 
A set of tariffs was devised for freight and passenger transport service, on the basis of 
full  cost  recovery  plus  an  adequate  return  on  equity.  Operating  revenues  from  tariffs  were 
projected on the basis of a forecast of future traffic and a base average tariff rate of CNY0.12 
per  ton-kilometer  (ton-km)  for  2015,  inclusive  of  Railway  Construction  Fund  collections,  which 
average CNY0.033 per ton-km. The freight tariff is assumed to increase at a rate of 1% yearly 
with  tariff  adjustments  taking  place  every  5  years.  Similar  to  the  freight  tariff,  passenger  fares 
are  assumed  to  increase  in  current  terms  once  every  5  years  at  an  annual  rate  of  1%. 
Passenger  tariff  ranges  from  CNY0.1  per  passenger-kilometer  (pass-km)  for  local  trains  to 
CNY0.20 per pass-km for very fast transit trains (200 km/hour) in 2015, with a weighted average

occur over the Project’s life span. Other revenues, including loading and unloading, warehouse 
storage, parcel service in the train stations, amount to 4.5% of combined freight and passenger 
revenue.  
 
3. 
All  incremental  operating  costs  are  projected  to  increase  yearly  with  inflation  rates.

be  replaced  after  15  years  of  operation  at  a  cost  of  CNY1,298.86  million,  and  signaling  and 
communications, safety, and other equipment will be replaced after 20 years of operation, at a 
cost of CNY650.99 million.  
 
4. 
Depreciation is calculated according to the straight-line method, with an average life of 
65 years for the main railway structure, 10 years for track, 45 years for buildings, 15 years for 
electric  power  and  traction,  and  20  years  for  signaling,  communications,  safety,  and  other 
equipment and facilities. Applicable business taxes, at an average rate of 3.24%, are charged 
on revenue. Corporate income tax, at 33%, is paid on income after deducting business taxes, 
depreciation  and  interest  charges,  operating  expenses,  and  any  prior  year  losses  carried 
forward.  
 
5.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

This Project is consistent  with the Country  Partnership Strategy,  which aims to enhance pro-poor economic growth through 
transport infrastructure development. The railway will serve a as key transport link for the western development region of the 
PRC.  Overall,  it  is  expected  that  the  Lanzhou–Chongqing  Railway  (LCR)  Development  Project  will  contribute  to  equitable 
economic  growth  by  (i)  improving  access  to  marketing  and  employment  opportunities;  (ii)  facilitating  access  to  key  social 
services;  (iii) supporting  and  stimulating  agricultural  production;  (iv)  promoting  trade,  encouraging  livelihood  diversification, 
and enabling information exchange; (v) improving a key component of regional and rural infrastructure and reducing widening 
gaps  in  living  standards  and  economic  opportunities  between  the  western  and  coastal  areas;  and  (vi)  removing  one  of  the 
constraints on the development of poor and rural communities. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                           Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
Development in the project impact area (PIA) has been constrained by limited transportation infrastructure, which is one factor 
contributing  to  the  relatively  high  incidence  of  poverty  in  some  areas.  The  28  counties  and  districts  in  the  PIA  include  15 
nationally designated poverty counties and 2,897 designated poverty villages (31% of all villages in the PIA). Better railway 
transport will provide an enabling condition for poverty reduction through improved access to markets, employment, education 
and  medical  facilities,  new  knowledge  and  information,  families  working  or  studying  in  other  regions,  and  other  social  and 
economic  services  that  facilitate  economic  development.  Improved  access  to  markets  will  open  up  opportunities  for  new 
enterprises  and  expansion  of  existing  ones.  Incoming  passengers  and  tourists  will  spawn  additional  demand  for  locally 
produced goods and services. 
 
2.  Design Features  
The construction and operation of the railway will generate significant employment in local communities, which will be targeted 
at local communities including poverty villages. Construction access and roads connecting to the railway will directly benefit 
poor villages by helping to extend the project benefits and opportunities to the poor communities. Station area development 
will encourage small business development among local people, including women and the poor.

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

Findings of Social Analysis  

A. 
A poverty and social assessment (PSA) has been prepared for the Project. This includes a poverty profile of beneficiaries and 
client groups and a social assessment. The beneficiaries of the Project have been identified through surveys, consultative 
fieldwork, and secondary sources. Beneficiaries can be broken down into (i) direct beneficiaries, i.e., existing rail users, and 
other transport users who might shift to rail, such as freight carriers, and passengers; and (ii) indirect beneficiaries, who do not 
necessarily rely on the railway but may derive some benefits including those in public sector employment, operators of small 
businesses such as shop owners and traders, farmers and farmers’ associations or cooperatives, people engaged in daily 
labor, construction workers, and tourists visiting or transiting the PIA.  

Economic conditions along the alignment range from relatively well off to some of the poorest in the PRC. Most of the villages 
along the alignment are isolated and have not been recipients of development. The links between poverty, topography, and 
transport systems are apparent in the PIA. People living in the mountains or in isolated areas lack fertile land and sufficient 
means of livelihood. They also live in areas prone to drought, frosts, erosion, and uncertainty. The main causes of poverty in 
the  project  areas  are  (i)  natural  calamity,  (ii)  lack  of  infrastructure,  (iii)  very  limited  and  unsustainable  sources  of  livelihood, 
(vi) uneven economic development, and (v) poor health. The Project will benefit about 16.8 million people in the PIA, of whom 
72% live in rural areas and 8% are designated poor (using the official absolute poverty line in the PRC of CNY693 per person 
per  year).  According  to  survey  data,  17%  of  households  are  poor  and  vulnerable  (with  annual  incomes  below  CNY1,000). 
Vulnerable  households  are  above  the  poverty  line  but  are  susceptible  to  economic  shocks  that  could  force  them  below  the 
poverty line. Few households have regular nonfarm income. The most predominant livelihood sector, on a regular or irregular 
basis, is agriculture, accounting for 80% of all working household members.  

About 467,913 unskilled person-years of work will be created during the construction of LCR. Half will target the poor, at total 
wages  of  CNY2,105  million  over  233,957  person-years,  or  CNY8,997  per  person-year—more  than  12  times  the  official 
poverty  line  of  CNY693  per  person  per  year.  Hiring  priority  will  be  given  to  women,  resettlement-affected  people,  and 
vulnerable  people.  In  addition,  during  the  construction,  80,693  person-years  of  local  unskilled  jobs  in  the  provision  of 
construction materials,  with total  wages of  CNY605.2 million,  will be created; again, half, or 40,346  person-years,  with total 
wages of CNY302.6 million will be set aside for the poor. When the new railway starts operating in 2015, about 3,460 more

B.  Consultation and Participation 

1. Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during the project preparation. 
 

The  PIA  of  LCR  includes  seven  prefectures  and  28  counties  in  Gansu,  Shaanxi,  and  Sichuan  provinces  and  Chongqing 
municipality.  Participation  has  included  surveys  and  community  consultation  (focus  group  meetings  and  interviews  with 
stakeholders).  About  3,900  household  surveys,  350  village  surveys,  and  200  industry  surveys,  as  well  as  770  passenger 
surveys, have been completed. During the household surveys, beneficiaries provided information on their perceptions of the 
Project:  overall,  94%  saw  the  Project  as  bringing  tangible  benefits  to  their  household,  while  5%  were  indifferent  and  1% 
expressed the view that that the Project would also have some adverse impact. 

Various  project  public  consultations  and  participation  activities  were  carried  out  in  2006–2007  and  the  role  of  each 
stakeholder has been identified. The Ministry of Railways (MOR), the First and Second Survey Design Institutes of China Rail, 
the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  consultant,  and  ADB  missions  have  had  formal  and  informal 
consultations  with  local  communities  and  government  agencies  through  meetings,  surveys,  household  interviews,  written 
communications, and workshops. Since the start of the feasibility studies some 14,000 individuals have been consulted about 
the  Project.  MOR  is  the  Executing  Agency  and  is  responsible  for  overall  supervision  and  implementation  of  construction 
activities. The local county and township governments and communities will assist the Executing Agency in land acquisition, 
the  implementation  of  the  resettlement  plan,  and  the  organization  of  local  labor  for  the  construction  and  local  development 
(including  the  station  areas)  to  ensure  that  the  Project  benefits  the  poor,  women,  ethnic  minorities,  and  other  vulnerable 
people.  Initial  issues  discussed  included  the  selection  of  the  alignment.  Further  public  consultation  occurred  during  various 
field surveys among local residents and government officials, tourists, passengers using all modes of transport, industries in 
the PIA, and other stakeholders.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 

 
The Project involves an 820 kilometer electrified double-track railway line from Lanzhou 
1. 
to Chongqing. The Lanzhou–Chongqing Railway (LCR)  Development  Project will cross Gansu 
and Sichuan provinces and Chongqing City and 28 counties and districts. Land acquisition and 
house  demolition  will  affect  94  townships  and  275  villages.  The  resettlement  impact  of  the 
Project  is  spread  thinly  over  a  long,  narrow  corridor.  The  resettlement  plan  addresses  the 
permanent and temporary impact caused by the railway alignment, station sites, station access 
roads, and related construction activities. The project scope does not include the proposed loop 
lines and rail yards in Lanzhou and Chongqing.  
 
2. 
An estimated 1,646 hectares of land will be permanently acquired. Of this, 31.0% will be 
paddy  land,  51.0%  cultivated  dryland,  0.8%  garden  or  orchard,  6.8%  forest  land,  6.4% 
residential land, and 2.7% wasteland. The Project will also temporarily acquire 1,388 hectares 
for LCR construction activities and access. A total of 1,189,240 square meters of structures will 
be  affected,  93.7%  of  which  will be residential  units  and  other  farm  structures,  5.3%  industrial 
structures,  and  1%  schools.  According  to  the  standard  for  impact  assessment  in  the  People’s 
Republic  of  China  (PRC),  the  equivalent  of  3,843  households  would  lose  all  their  land  and 
agricultural livelihoods, and 12,072 households would have their houses demolished. Since the 
alignment is narrow, most land impact will be partial, resulting in more affected households with 
less significant impact. From previous experience with PRC railways, it is estimated partial land 
impact  in  the  order  of  15%  along  the  route  and  33%  at  stations  will  be  experienced,  affecting 
about  81,366  affected  people  and  21,469  households  through  permanent  land  acquisition.  In 
addition,  an  estimated  6,935  households  (26,283  people)  are  expected  to  be  affected  by 
temporary land acquisition. Land acquisition and resettlement (LAR) impact has been lessened 
by  aligning  the  railway  away  from  the  most  densely  populated  areas,  and  avoiding  villages, 
cultivated land, and facilities where possible; 72.6% of the alignment is tunnels or bridges.  
 
3. 
The resettlement objective is to ensure that compensation and entitlements provided to 
affected persons are adequate to at least maintain their "without-Project" standard of living, with 
prospects of improvement, in line with the PRC Land Administration Law (amended 2004) and 
with ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). In addition, affected people that are poor or 
vulnerable should be made better off, either as direct beneficiaries or through special measures 
to safeguard and enhance their living conditions. People losing land, housing, other assets, or 
other  means  of  production  will  be  compensated  at  replacement  cost  and  assisted  in  restoring 
their incomes and living standards. Payments for land will be made to the village collectives, and 
they  will  determine  how  the  funds  should  be  allocated  among  the  affected  persons.  Village 
rehabilitation plans will be prepared for stations that cause serious impact on affected villages; 
these plans will be integrated with station area development plans. 
 
4. 
The resettlement plan stipulates eligibility and entitlement provisions for affected persons. 
The  Project  will  ensure  that  land  compensation  will  not  be  less  than  16  times  the  average 
annual output value. Compensation for temporary land loss will be paid directly to the affected 
persons  and  the  land  will  be  restored  to  its  original  state  after  use.  Compensation  for  rural 
housing  losses  will  be  paid  directly  to  the  affected  persons  at  replacement  cost,  free  of 
depreciation,  demolition  expenses,  and  salvaged  materials.  In  general,  rural  households  will 
either rebuild their own houses within the same village or integrated with the centrally planned 
suburban  housing.  Better  road  access  and  provision  of  site  leveling,  water  supply,  electricity, 
telephone,  and  cable  facilities  will  be  provided.  Urban  households  may  choose  to  be 
(i) allocated  replacement  housing  on  the  basis  of  a  swap  of  property  rights  for  properties  of 
equivalent size and quality, or (ii) paid cash compensation at the market  price with which they 
may purchase replacement housing in the real estate market. Compensation for crop and tree 
losses will be paid directly to the affected persons. Factories, schools, and other institutions and 
enterprises  will  be  compensated  after  a  process  of  negotiation.  Local  government  will  finance 
the improvement of affected schools.

5. 
The Ministry of Railways (MOR), with the assistance of the First and Second Survey and 
Design Institutes, conducted a survey of 1,565 potentially affected households in August 2006. 
Also,  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  consultant  surveyed  355  villages  and  1,167

CNY1,000 per capita. Special measures are included in the resettlement plan for the poor and 
other  vulnerable  groups  to  ensure  they  are  adequately  rehabilitated  and  their  living  standards 
improved. Ethnic minority households constitute 2% of the population in the project area; most 
are Hui living in cities.  
 
6. 
Each village or affected person will use the land compensation and resettlement subsidy 
for income restoration. Local officials have indicated that schools, factories, and enterprises will 
rebuild  locally  and  that  these  organizations  and  their  employees  will  be  fully  compensated  for 
any  and  all  losses  and  costs  associated  with  relocation.  Affected  households  will  receive 
training  and  skills  development  assistance  that  will  facilitate  income-generating  activities.  An 
income  restoration  budget  has  been  included  to  meet  the  costs  of  extension  of  services  to 
affected  persons  and  others  in  affected  villages  in  areas  such  as  agricultural  extension, 
cooperative  marketing  and  organization  for  agricultural  produce,  agricultural  and  enterprise 
credit,  and  other  needs  that  arise  during  detailed  resettlement  planning  and  implementation. 
Other assistance, such as preferential hiring of affected persons by construction companies and 
access to capital, will also be provided. 
 
7. 
Affected persons have been informed and consulted at various stages about the project 
impact  and  resettlement  policies  and  entitlements.  They  will  continue  to  be  consulted  and  are 
encouraged to participate in resettlement activities, including the detailed measurement survey, 
location  of  underpasses,  new  housing  sites,  and  grievance  redress.  Affected  persons  can 
appeal  any  problems  or  grievances  regarding  land  acquisition,  housing  demolition  and 
relocation,  compensation,  and  resettlement  to  five  levels:  the  village  committee,  the  railway 
construction  support  office  (RCSO),  local  government,  the  project  company,  the  independent 
monitor, or the courts. A resettlement information booklet was provided by MOR to all affected 
villages in October 2007. The resettlement plan will be updated on the basis of the inventory of 
losses and the final alignment. 
 
8. 
Local government RCSOs, set up under the local development and reform commissions, 
will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the  resettlement;  the  offices  at  the  county  or  district  level 
will  coordinate  the  administrative  LAR  activities,  with  assistance  from  township  officials  and 
village  committees.  MOR  will  monitor  the  LAR  activities  and  supervise  the  contractors  with 
respect to temporary impact. MOR and the local governments have extensive experience with 
resettlement. The local government will provide training to local officials who will be involved in 
implementation.  MOR  and  the  project  company,  in  collaboration  with  the  RCSOs,  will  be 
responsible for internal supervision and monitoring of resettlement. An independent monitor will 
be contracted by MOR to carry out the external monitoring and evaluation work.  
 
The  total  resettlement  cost  for  the  Project  is  CNY2.1  billion,  including  taxes  and 
9. 
contingencies. The budget will be adjusted on the basis of the actual measurement of physical 
losses.  Each  provincial  government1 will  be  responsible  for  resettlement  costs  as  part  of  its 
equity in the Project Company. The local governments will supplement the resettlement budget, 
as  may  prove  necessary,  to  meet  any  shortfall.  The  implementation  schedule  is  based  on  the 
proposed  project  construction  timetable.  Land  acquisition  will  begin  in  December  2008  and 
finished in early 2012. The Project will be completed in 2015.
